title: How to Make Primitive Utensils, Pots and Pans Without Using Metal

steps.headline: Take a piece of clay roughly as big as your hand, and warm it up.
steps.description: You can do this by squeezing it for a minute or two. This helps because as the clay is heated, the molecules expand, which makes the clay softer and easier to work with.

steps.headline: Roll it into a ball.
steps.description: You do this by lightly pressing while making circular waving motions with your hand on the clay. It doesn't have to be perfect, it will even itself out a little in the next step.

steps.headline: 'Stab' the clay ball.
steps.description: Now, since this is primitive pottery NO POTTERY WHEELS, sorry! OK, now do something VERY sophisticated. "Stab" the clay with your thumb. Come on, really do it hard! But Be careful to leave at least half an inch thick bottom, or your bowl may break!

steps.headline: Now if you choose to make your bowl wider, use your fingers to to pull outwards and evenly on all sides.
steps.description: Or you can make it taller by repeating this motion, but not very much, then pinching and pulling upwards. Don't exaggerate height nor width as the bowl may break. There must be enough clay in all areas to support itself!

steps.headline: Make ruffles around the top by thinning it out (at top only) and then pinching it together in small units.
steps.description: Just do what makes you happy!

steps.headline: Bake your pottery.
steps.description: Just put the right temperature your package says, and cook for 15-20 minutes.

steps.headline: Now when you pop it out, resist the temptation to jab it with a knife to see how hard it is.
steps.description: The clay is softer when first out of the oven then when cooled down. The overall result will be harder if you pop it directly in the freezer when out of the oven. Do this immediately!

steps.headline: Make it look old.
steps.description: Use pale yellow paint as the base. Then do your "Tribal" designs. When finished, you can use the lighter to burn parts of the bowl. DO NOT PUT THE FLAME DIRECTLY ON THE BOWL! This will result in the bowl igniting. Instead leave the flame an inch or two away until the area you're heating is light brown at the center. That's your bowl!

steps.headline: For spoon take the clay and make a cylinder about as long as you want the spoon handle to be.
While making the handle leave a 2 inch (5.1 cm) by 2 inch (5.1 cm) squarish shape hanging off.
Repeat all spoon steps, except instead of making a mini bowl, cut into 3 or 4 blunt rectangles.
Bake, same process as last time but more 10-15 minutes depending on thickness.
Now, for spoon you are done!
steps.description: For fork just use knife to sharpen prongs.

steps.headline: Of course do any details you want
For the pan make a wide, short bowl, and make a giant spoon handle!

text: Shaman style bowl Take a piece of clay roughly as big as your hand, and warm it up. You can do this by squeezing it for a minute or two. This helps because as the clay is heated, the molecules expand, which makes the clay softer and easier to work with. Roll it into a ball. You do this by lightly pressing while making circular waving motions with your hand on the clay. It doesn't have to be perfect, it will even itself out a little in the next step. 'Stab' the clay ball. Now, since this is primitive pottery NO POTTERY WHEELS, sorry! OK, now do something VERY sophisticated. "Stab" the clay with your thumb. Come on, really do it hard! But Be careful to leave at least half an inch thick bottom, or your bowl may break! Now if you choose to make your bowl wider, use your fingers to to pull outwards and evenly on all sides. Or you can make it taller by repeating this motion, but not very much, then pinching and pulling upwards. Don't exaggerate height nor width as the bowl may break. There must be enough clay in all areas to support itself! Make ruffles around the top by thinning it out (at top only) and then pinching it together in small units. Just do what makes you happy! Bake your pottery. Just put the right temperature your package says, and cook for 15-20 minutes. Now when you pop it out, resist the temptation to jab it with a knife to see how hard it is. The clay is softer when first out of the oven then when cooled down. The overall result will be harder if you pop it directly in the freezer when out of the oven. Do this immediately! Make it look old. Use pale yellow paint as the base. Then do your "Tribal" designs. When finished, you can use the lighter to burn parts of the bowl. DO NOT PUT THE FLAME DIRECTLY ON THE BOWL! This will result in the bowl igniting. Instead leave the flame an inch or two away until the area you're heating is light brown at the center. That's your bowl! Spoon and Fork For spoon take the clay and make a cylinder about as long as you want the spoon handle to be.  While making the handle leave a 2 inch (5.1 cm) by 2 inch (5.1 cm) squarish shape hanging off. Repeat step 3 of bowl. Repeat all spoon steps, except instead of making a mini bowl, cut into 3 or 4 blunt rectangles.  Bake, same process as last time but more 10-15 minutes depending on thickness.  Now, for spoon you are done! For fork just use knife to sharpen prongs. Of course do any details you want  For the pan make a wide, short bowl, and make a giant spoon handle!
